excerpts: The flour drop soup was made vegetarian for me, very kindly.
It was overflowing & flavorful.
flour drop soup.author: Lani C.
flour drop soup.review: Popped in here randomly en route to the Legion of Honor, and it was wonderful!  The staff was friendly & helpful.  (They really look out for vegetarians & any personal allergies, when you make it clear what you need.  I appreciate that so much!!)  The menu is clear & easy to understand (photos! yes!).  The flour drop soup was made vegetarian for me, very kindly.  It was overflowing & flavorful.  The red bean bun hit the spot, as I wanted to munch on something sweet.  It was all fresh and delicious.  I can't wait to try more of their menu.  Thank you, Village House!

excerpts: We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao.
Everything tasted great and was delicious.
The service was also good.
The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea.
egg with tomato noodle soup.author: Gabriel H.
egg with tomato noodle soup.review: Was looking for a place to eat around the area and my girlfriend stumbled upon this restaurant on yelp so we decided to give it a try since they have handmade dumplings and noodles and I must say it was as good as we expected and it didn't disappoint at all. We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao. Everything tasted great and was delicious. The service was also good. The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea. He even gave us a free sesame red bean pancake as a dessert. We're definitely coming back to try some of the other delicious looking food on their menu.

excerpts: Had the Beef Tendon Noodle Soup to go.
It was not a good experience.
There was not a single piece of tendon in there.
What I did find were thick slices of very dry, under-seasoned beef in a greasy soup.
And it's definitely overpriced at $9.95.
beef tendon noodle soup.author: David W.
beef tendon noodle soup.review: Had the Beef Tendon Noodle Soup to go. It was not a good experience. There was not a single piece of tendon in there. What I did find were thick slices of very dry, under-seasoned beef in a greasy soup. And it's definitely overpriced at $9.95.

excerpts: My friend and I ordered the braised beef noodle soup, spicy dumplings, xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and garlic bok choy.
Everything made fresh from scratch.
Even the garlic was freshly shaved.
Really good!
Give them a try.
braised beef noodle soup.author: Aaron W.
braised beef noodle soup.review: Beijing hand made dumpling and noodles. Great service! Very reasonable prices. My friend and I ordered the braised beef noodle soup, spicy dumplings, xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and garlic bok choy. Everything made fresh from scratch. Even the garlic was freshly shaved. Really good! Give them a try.

excerpts: Braised beef noodle soup, xiaolong bao, salt & pepper chix wings, spicy green beans, red bean dessert, all the dumplings...
Omgosh you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu.
Great prices, wonderful service; like home cooked comfort food.
It's a hole in the wall.
When we see  people pop their heads in then leave, we always think, "Too bad.
You don't know what you're missing.
Owner did a recent 'renovation' which is kind of cute as it now has tiny red lanterns hanging everywhere.
It's midnight as I type this review and damnit, I want some dumplings...
braised beef noodle soup.author: M F.
braised beef noodle soup.review: When folks visit us in SF, we bring them to Village House and they love it, too. Braised beef noodle soup, xiaolong bao, salt & pepper chix wings, spicy green beans, red bean dessert, all the dumplings... Omgosh you cannot go wrong with anything on the menu. Great prices, wonderful service; like home cooked comfort food. It's a hole in the wall. When we see  people pop their heads in then leave, we always think, "Too bad. You don't know what you're missing." Owner did a recent 'renovation' which is kind of cute as it now has tiny red lanterns hanging everywhere. It's midnight as I type this review and damnit, I want some dumplings...

excerpts:
We had the following dishes:

(1) braised beef noodle soup.
braised beef noodle soup.author: A L.
braised beef noodle soup.review:
Homemade and so good! We ate here tonight (dine-in, not take-out). The gal who served us (young gal with glasses) was really nice and attentive and service was great. We had the following dishes:

(1) braised beef noodle soup. I really loved the broth. It's not as salty as other restaurants which I like. Tons of flavor, the noodles were chewy and fresh, and the beef was pretty lean and so tender! 

(2) pork and shrimp and chive dumplings. So good! And the meat is already seasoned perfectly so I wouldn't recommend dipping these in soy sauce or any kind of sauce, just eat them plain. The wrapper was homemade and fresh. 

(3) xlb. Another winner! Delicate light and full of flavorful soup, just how good xlb should be. 

(4) green onion pancakes. Crispy fried on the outside, doughy and chewy on the inside, just delicious. 

(5) steamed red bean bun. This was the only disappointing dish, I wouldn't recommend this one. 

Will definitely go back!

excerpts: I ate lamb dumpling and braised beef noodle soup .
It taste very good .
I'm going to try different food next time .
braised beef noodle soup.author: Sisi W.
braised beef noodle soup.review: I love the dumpling and noodle because they're all handmade . It really healthy and good quality for me ,even for everyone . I ate lamb dumpling and braised beef noodle soup . It taste very good . I'm going to try different food next time .

excerpts: We had the XLB, beef roll, braised eggplant, and Beijing bean sauce noodles.
The location is easy to get too but hard to find parking around especially on the weekend.
beijing bean sauce noodles.author: Vanessa S.
beijing bean sauce noodles.review: Came here to have brunch with friends, and have to admit the food was pretty good but some of the dishes were a bit too bland for my tastes. We had the XLB, beef roll, braised eggplant, and Beijing bean sauce noodles. The location is easy to get too but hard to find parking around especially on the weekend.

excerpts: We ordered beef noodle soup, wonton noodle soup, spring rolls (the BEST spring rolls I have ever had: packed with veggies, not dry or over-fried, so tasty), shredded pork in wonton wrappers, and black bean noodles.
Unbelievably happy with every single dish--the noodles are hand rolled and cut with a great texture, and the soups were incredibly flavorful.
The bok choy dish was a huge hit too -- I don't know what they did to this classic veggie dish, but it was unbelievably tasty.
wonton noodle soup.author: L T.
wonton noodle soup.review:
Absolutely scrumptious! We ordered beef noodle soup, wonton noodle soup, spring rolls (the BEST spring rolls I have ever had: packed with veggies, not dry or over-fried, so tasty), shredded pork in wonton wrappers, and black bean noodles. Unbelievably happy with every single dish--the noodles are hand rolled and cut with a great texture, and the soups were incredibly flavorful. The bok choy dish was a huge hit too -- I don't know what they did to this classic veggie dish, but it was unbelievably tasty. Dessert = red bean pancakes, hot out of the oven, sweet and with heapings of red bean filling. 

Service was fast but not so fast that we felt rushed. Waitress and the chef (he came out to say hello and refill our tea) were so nice and welcoming. I will definitely be back with another large group! One of my new favorite restaurants in the Richmond for sure.

excerpts: I came here after a round of golf and got the xiao long bao, pig ears, and beef noodle soup.
All were fantastic...great tea too (for free).
pig ears.author: Jimmy D.
pig ears.review: Excellent food, excellent service. I came here after a round of golf and got the xiao long bao, pig ears, and beef noodle soup. All were fantastic...great tea too (for free).

excerpts:
Cold chilled julienne cut pig ears in a just right at jus.  
3.5-4   stars
             
Tomato beef chow mein, off the menu.
pig ears.author: Jim M.
pig ears.review:
I like this Quant 10 month newbie.  Nice to go post opening.  Local regulars were in the mix on a Saturday afternoon.  Glad I picked up the menu to absorb it's eclectic and enticing Beijing style cuisine.  Altho many Asian eateries along Balboa.  This is located in a unhurried environment.  Kinda.

So I sat down to Andrea's librarian and intellectual but curious smile.  Was she thinking of me staying? I did.  So I just went exotic and old school native The City boy.  I was welcome to use my personal thermos cup for tea.  No need to b Ave t b email was another pot.  Let what looked like her mom & dad curious to hear a local born voice with a nowhere accent.  Lol

Order:  Cold chilled julienne cut pig ears in a just right at jus.  
3.5-4   stars
             
Tomato beef chow mein, off the menu. 3.5-4  stars

 Why you ask off the menu?  Well being concierge back in the day.  It shows their ability to prepare at a moments nice.  Very key in hospitality.
So one great feature of there diverse kitchen.  They make their own noodles.   
Check it out!

excerpts: the chicken dumpling with green chives is the only one that really blew my mind.
The potstickers, which are typically one of my favorite dishes, were a total disappointment.
They charge $5.95 for 4 doughy, flavorless pockets of disappointment.
I can go to any number of other dim sum places and get 3 for around $2.
The spicy dumplings, which were recommended to me as their most popular dish tasted okay, but made me feel ill later that day.
Also, more than one my dishes were swimming in oil, which somewhat ruined it for me.
chicken dumpling with green chives.author: Chris S.
chicken dumpling with green chives.review:
After the previous (and my favorite) dim sum place at this location closed, I was fairly apprehensive about Village House when it opened. When I first walked in I was pleasantly surprised to find that they make all their dim sum fresh, right up front for everyone to see. The atmosphere of the place is nice as well. It's small, quiet, clean and pleasantly decorated. The staff is courteous and more than willing to answer any questions you may have. The size of the menu is decent for a place like this, but what's on the menu is fairly uninspired. There isn't much you won't find at any other generic Chinese-American restaurant. The real question is... is the food any good? 

I have been to Village House half a dozen times over the span of a few weeks to try and get a sense of quality and consistency. Unfortunately, they are one of the most inconsistent restaurants I have ever experienced. The dim sum has ranged from absolutely outstanding to a doughy, under-seasoned mess. the chicken dumpling with green chives is the only one that really blew my mind. The potstickers, which are typically one of my favorite dishes, were a total disappointment. They charge $5.95 for 4 doughy, flavorless pockets of disappointment. I can go to any number of other dim sum places and get 3 for around $2. The spicy dumplings, which were recommended to me as their most popular dish tasted okay, but made me feel ill later that day. Also, more than one my dishes were swimming in oil, which somewhat ruined it for me. Out of curiosity I tried the Chinese hamburger. It's simple and delicious. I just wish it had more filling. I would recommend it as a late-afternoon snack to anyone walking by looking for a quick bite to eat. My biggest complaint about this place isn't actually about the quality of the food it's the fact that everything is made to order, which in this case is actually a detriment to their business model. Dim sum restaurants are supposed to be fast and have small portioned, good quality dumplings at affordable prices. Village House doesn't really offer that. The prices are too high for the quality of food they provide and because everything is made to order, you have to wait a minimum of 10 minutes for even a single order of dim sum. I haven't tried any of their soups yet and I have seen quite a few people ordering it when they eat in the restaurant. They look quite good and I look forward to trying them. Although my experiences with Village House have not been the best so far, I will go again to try different things and see if their consistency improves. 

Overall I believe Village House has the potential to be a great, local dim sum place, but at this point I wouldn't recommend ordering any of the actual dumplings. It is a good place to bring a date for a small meal before seeing a movie at the theater down the street. It's a quiet and pleasant experience, even if the food is subpar.

excerpts: * Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs.
The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu.
Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.
spicy dumpling.author: Sterling C.
spicy dumpling.review: ***One of the best places for quick, inexpensive and delicious Chinese snack/dim sum dishes.*** Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs. The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu. Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.

excerpts: I also had a bbq pork bun that was super yummy.
Not only are the people who work here super nice, but the value for price can't be beat.
I'll be be back to try more menu item.
Highly recommend.
bbq pork bun.author: Meg F.
bbq pork bun.review: Wow! Such great noodles. House made noodles with the perfect consistency...so good.  I was in the neighborhood looking for some tasty food and village house hit the spot. I also had a bbq pork bun that was super yummy.  Not only are the people who work here super nice, but the value for price can't be beat.  I'll be be back to try more menu item.  Highly recommend.

excerpts: I was also really craving a baked BBQ pork bun--a staple in dim sum--and they didn't have any!
bbq pork bun.author: Amy B.
bbq pork bun.review:
I really wanted to like this place since I loved the previous dim sum place that was at this location. When we couldn't find parking for Hong Kong Lounge, we decided to come home and walk a block to Village House. It was, in a word, disappointing. The dumplings were very doughy and bland. The fillings were also pretty tasteless. I was also really craving a baked BBQ pork bun--a staple in dim sum--and they didn't have any! 

I was heartened, though, they they do in fact take credit cards, despite the "cash only" sign on the window. 

I might be willing to try again considering this is a neighborhood place and I like supporting small businesses in my hood. But I won't have high hopes. Sigh.

excerpts: The red bean bun hit the spot, as I wanted to munch on something sweet.
It was all fresh and delicious.
I can't wait to try more of their menu.
Thank you, Village House!
red bean bun.author: Lani C.
red bean bun.review: Popped in here randomly en route to the Legion of Honor, and it was wonderful!  The staff was friendly & helpful.  (They really look out for vegetarians & any personal allergies, when you make it clear what you need.  I appreciate that so much!!)  The menu is clear & easy to understand (photos! yes!).  The flour drop soup was made vegetarian for me, very kindly.  It was overflowing & flavorful.  The red bean bun hit the spot, as I wanted to munch on something sweet.  It was all fresh and delicious.  I can't wait to try more of their menu.  Thank you, Village House!

excerpts: (5) steamed red bean bun.
red bean bun.author: A L.
red bean bun.review:
Homemade and so good! We ate here tonight (dine-in, not take-out). The gal who served us (young gal with glasses) was really nice and attentive and service was great. We had the following dishes:

(1) braised beef noodle soup. I really loved the broth. It's not as salty as other restaurants which I like. Tons of flavor, the noodles were chewy and fresh, and the beef was pretty lean and so tender! 

(2) pork and shrimp and chive dumplings. So good! And the meat is already seasoned perfectly so I wouldn't recommend dipping these in soy sauce or any kind of sauce, just eat them plain. The wrapper was homemade and fresh. 

(3) xlb. Another winner! Delicate light and full of flavorful soup, just how good xlb should be. 

(4) green onion pancakes. Crispy fried on the outside, doughy and chewy on the inside, just delicious. 

(5) steamed red bean bun. This was the only disappointing dish, I wouldn't recommend this one. 

Will definitely go back!

excerpts: Often I get their frozen steamed buns to go and cook them at home later.
I always feel good after a meal.
steamed buns.author: Austin C.
steamed buns.review: These folk know Chinese food!  I love eating here.  Often I get their frozen steamed buns to go and cook them at home later.  I always feel good after a meal.

excerpts: If you want some homemade dumplings, steamed buns, potsticker, pancakes, and noodle soup, here is the place to go.
steamed buns.author: Yuan Z.
steamed buns.review:
I am very excited to see this place open in my neighborhood, although I did go to Jook Time (the previous Cantonese/Dim Sum restaurant) a lot. The sitting area is bigger, and food is more stewed,  boiled and steamed than deep fried. You can see ladies making dumplings or buns out in the front. 

If you want some homemade dumplings, steamed buns, potsticker, pancakes, and noodle soup, here is the place to go. It's northern style Chinese food (Hebei). 

They are very generous on their portions. The broth of the noodles taste so yummy and healthy. They also offer lunch boxes and their price is very good. 

I havent tried their stir-fried dishes yet, but i am eyeing on the Xinjiang Style Spicy Chicken over Noodles. 

So far my favorites are:
-Dumplings
-Beef pancake
-Beef noodles soup
-Dumpling noodle soup

excerpts: Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach.
pork chow mein.author: Johanna-Joy G.
pork chow mein.review: Tasty food, friendly place. Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach. Walnut prawns and pork/shrimp dumplings were our fav!!

excerpts: What I like is their boiled fish with szhuan pickles (suggest getting mild, it's pretty spicy) and their seafood fried noodles.
Do not get the soy milk.
It's watered down and tastes like artificial milk.
We had to toss the 2 cups we ordered.
Overall, I can't say they are bad, but again it's not always consistent.
seafood fried noodles.author: Amy T.
seafood fried noodles.review: I feel this place is a hit or miss. Sometimes we order to go and good would taste great and well balanced of flavors. At other times, things are either too salty, too bland, or too spicy. What I like is their boiled fish with szhuan pickles (suggest getting mild, it's pretty spicy) and their seafood fried noodles. Do not get the soy milk. It's watered down and tastes like artificial milk. We had to toss the 2 cups we ordered. Overall, I can't say they are bad, but again it's not always consistent.

excerpts: Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes!
Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?!
So very good!
Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.
dry fried chicken wings.author: E W.
dry fried chicken wings.review:
Friendly, family run small neighborhood restaurant. Great trying Sichuan food here and Cantonese dishes too. Their large soup noodle bowls are yummy and perfectly satisfying  for those cold days! Especially enjoyed their preserved/pickled  vegetable dishes! Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes! Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?! So very good! Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.

excerpts: And I love the Dry Fried Chicken Wings too.
The wings are really juicy and mouthwatering!
I give five stars for this Chinese restaurant, because of the professional chefs and great service.
Village House made me feel like I was back to home.
I love it!
dry fried chicken wings.author: Peng L.
dry fried chicken wings.review: Loved the taste. Especially the Spicy Dumplings. The souse tastes just as same as the original souse in SiChuan, China. And I love the Dry Fried Chicken Wings too. The wings are really juicy and mouthwatering!  I give five stars for this Chinese restaurant, because of the professional chefs and great service. Village House made me feel like I was back to home. I love it!

excerpts: Had chicken and chive dumplings, Kung pao chicken, braised eggplant, and hot & sour soup.
Service was very attentive and friendly.
Great neighborhood spot!
kung pao chicken.author: Alex R.
kung pao chicken.review: Very fresh, clean, delicious food! Had chicken and chive dumplings, Kung pao chicken, braised eggplant, and hot & sour soup. Service was very attentive and friendly. Great neighborhood spot!

excerpts: The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.
Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.
kung pao chicken.author: Christopher H.
kung pao chicken.review: Where to start...it recently (in the last year) went through a modest little makeover of the facade and brick outside and may have under gone a management change also??  This place is a diamond in the rough to have on Balboa.  Many thanks to the owners/staff who run the place now.  Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite

excerpts: * Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs.
The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu.
Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.
cumin beef.author: Sterling C.
cumin beef.review: ***One of the best places for quick, inexpensive and delicious Chinese snack/dim sum dishes.*** Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs. The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu. Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.

excerpts: I really liked the pan fried pork buns, red oil dumplings, fennel dumplings, cumin beef spareribs, and onion pancake.
I will definitely be coming back here when I'm in the neighborhoods again.
cumin beef.author: Tiffany S.
cumin beef.review: I came here with 2 other friends at 1:30 pm after hiking around Land's End on Saturday. It's a very close drive from Land's End, and we only waited 15 minutes. The chef was very friendly and recommended some good dishes for us. I really liked the pan fried pork buns, red oil dumplings, fennel dumplings, cumin beef spareribs, and onion pancake. I will definitely be coming back here when I'm in the neighborhoods again.

excerpts: We went there during lunchtime and ordered Mongolian lamb and beef, beef chow mein, "Chinese hamburger" (jia mo) with a soup.
The selection is nothing extraordinary but the experience was quite satisfying.
mongolian lamb.author: Kit R.
mongolian lamb.review: Owners are very friendly and the portions are pretty good for the price. Most dishes were right around $10. We went there during lunchtime and ordered Mongolian lamb and beef, beef chow mein, "Chinese hamburger" (jia mo) with a soup. The selection is nothing extraordinary but the experience was quite satisfying.

excerpts:
I've gotten to the point where I can trust my gut (literally and figuratively) and we selected several dishes that let the true regionality shine including: 
Shredded Pork with Bean Curd Skin, Ro Ja Moa (aka Chinese "Hamburger"), Cumin Lamb, Hot and Sour Potato, Chao Bing
cumin lamb.author: Michael T.
cumin lamb.review:
If you look at a map of China you'll notice it's a massive country, with numerous geographic regions, each with their own cuisine. Believe it or not, you can subdivide those regions even further into an almost innumerable variety of regional cuisines. It's where two regions (and their unique cultures) overlap that you find some of the most magical food.

We came to the Richmond in search of Shanghainese food, and we found an even more specific variation of that cuisine, with influences of the Muslim culture from the western part of China, here at Village House. 

As with most great Chinese eats in the US, you've gotta look past the recognizable items on the menu and dig to uncover the unique specialties of the house. I've gotten to the point where I can trust my gut (literally and figuratively) and we selected several dishes that let the true regionality shine including: 
Shredded Pork with Bean Curd Skin, Ro Ja Moa (aka Chinese "Hamburger"), Cumin Lamb, Hot and Sour Potato, Chao Bing (stir fried shredded pancake with beef and bean sprouts), AND hand folded lamb and zucchini dumplings. 

Hard to pick a favorite from that lineup because they all had their own unique merits, but I think I fell in love with the dish that sounds the simplest... hot and sour potato. Chinese chefs are masterful with their cleaver, and to julienne a potato by hand is no small feat. The uniformity in the cutting and cooking was truly impressive, and the sour and spicy sauce made this simple dish a beautiful marriage of flavor and texture that perfectly interrupted some of the richer dishes on the table. 

I'd have to say my second favorite was the shredded pork with bean curd skin. The shredded pork is coated in a glistening sweet sauce and set atop a pile of sliced cucumbers and bean sprouts, garnished with fresh cilantro and surrounded by squares of bean curd skin. As with many Chinese dishes, elements combine flavors and textures for the perfect bite, and in this one, the pork is so tender delicate that the bean curd adds in the chew while the veggies add in some freshness. 

Lastly, you can't help but notice the prep area dedicated to dumplings here. These aren't the intricate Cantonese dim sum dumplings you might've enjoyed elsewhere, but rather these are simple, handmade, and comforting dumplings, quickly boiled and served with black vinegar for dipping. They seem to make them by the bushel, almost to order, and you should absolutely try them when you're here.

If you're unfamiliar with this cuisine, I'd suggest repeating our order because it really hits some high notes. We were a party of three and ordered enough food for six, and yet our bill was still only $30/pp with tax and tip. I craved these flavors for the next few days. Absolutely delicious, unique, and impressively affordable.

excerpts: The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me
and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.
Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite

Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite

excerpts: Our party of three shared the braised tofu, shredded potato + green pepper, and mixed veggies and we had enough to take home some leftovers!
Everything was absolutely delicious and came out super fast even though the restaurant was packed.
Our server was attentive and speedy as well as patient while we decided what we wanted.
Would absolutely recommend and will definitely be back!!
braised tofu.author: Kat C.
braised tofu.review: Excellent dinner tonight!! Our party of three shared the braised tofu, shredded potato + green pepper, and mixed veggies and we had enough to take home some leftovers! Everything was absolutely delicious and came out super fast even though the restaurant was packed. Our server was attentive and speedy as well as patient while we decided what we wanted. Would absolutely recommend and will definitely be back!!

excerpts: We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao.
Everything tasted great and was delicious.
The service was also good.
The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea.
braised tofu.author: Gabriel H.
braised tofu.review: Was looking for a place to eat around the area and my girlfriend stumbled upon this restaurant on yelp so we decided to give it a try since they have handmade dumplings and noodles and I must say it was as good as we expected and it didn't disappoint at all. We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao. Everything tasted great and was delicious. The service was also good. The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea. He even gave us a free sesame red bean pancake as a dessert. We're definitely coming back to try some of the other delicious looking food on their menu.

excerpts: My favorite items are the braised tofu, green scallion pancakes and spicy dumplings.
So goof!
braised tofu.author: David A.
braised tofu.review: Love the Village House! My favorite items are the braised tofu, green scallion pancakes and spicy dumplings. So goof!

excerpts: We really love the braised tofu ... tofu is perfect.
Otherwise - we are dumpling fans and we always have their frozen dumplings in our freezer (awesome that they sell these) just in case we need to eat some and we are too lazy to leave the house
braised tofu.author: leslie y.
braised tofu.review: We really like this place. Friendly service and good food. We really love the braised tofu ... tofu is perfect. Otherwise - we are dumpling fans and we always have their frozen dumplings in our freezer (awesome that they sell these) just in case we need to eat some and we are too lazy to leave the house

excerpts: My friend and I ordered the braised beef noodle soup, spicy dumplings, xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and garlic bok choy.
Everything made fresh from scratch.
Even the garlic was freshly shaved.
Really good!
Give them a try.
garlic bok choy.author: Aaron W.
garlic bok choy.review: Beijing hand made dumpling and noodles. Great service! Very reasonable prices. My friend and I ordered the braised beef noodle soup, spicy dumplings, xiao long bao (soup dumplings) and garlic bok choy. Everything made fresh from scratch. Even the garlic was freshly shaved. Really good! Give them a try.

excerpts: Try the garlic bok choy!
garlic bok choy.author: Janzen A.
garlic bok choy.review: The staff is really nice and the food reminds me of good home cooking! Try the garlic bok choy!

excerpts: Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach.
garlic spinach.author: Johanna-Joy G.
garlic spinach.review: Tasty food, friendly place. Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach. Walnut prawns and pork/shrimp dumplings were our fav!!

excerpts: Add some Honey walnut prawns & shrimp chow mein to throw a little seafood in the mix.
Pork buns are tasty but have a little too much "bun" to it.
If you don't have a preference, order it.
walnut prawns.author: Angella G.
walnut prawns.review:
The dumplings here are the bomb, you can't go wrong with the dumplings you get! Our personal favs are the pork & cabbage, soups dumplings & the potstickers. Add some Honey walnut prawns & shrimp chow mein to throw a little seafood in the mix. Pork buns are tasty but have a little too much "bun" to it. If you don't have a preference, order it. The pork is really good! 

It's also the first place I've seen hot & sour soup with cilantro in it... the soup wasn't bad but it wasn't good. The cilantro was just too much and gave the soup an interesting flavor.

excerpts: We had the spicy dumplings, pan fried pork buns, and honey walnut prawns.
They were all top notch and would highly recommend them all!
The customer service can't be beat.
I would give this 10 stars if I could!
walnut prawns.author: Eric P.
walnut prawns.review: We happened upon this place because the restaurant we were looking for was closed. And we are so lucky it happened that way! We had the spicy dumplings, pan fried pork buns, and honey walnut prawns. They were all top notch and would highly recommend them all! The customer service can't be beat. I would give this 10 stars if I could!

excerpts: Walnut prawns and pork/shrimp dumplings were our fav!!
walnut prawns.author: Johanna-Joy G.
walnut prawns.review: Tasty food, friendly place. Ordered pork fried rice, pork chow mein, garlic spinach. Walnut prawns and pork/shrimp dumplings were our fav!!

excerpts: but I got some pot stickers because I was starving.
The cost was $4 for 3 pot stickers!
It was pretty pricy
but again I was starving.
Before handing them over the lady asked if I wanted them microwaved because they were cold.
I just grabbed them and left after paying for them.
They were not only cold, but also pretty gross.
I will never go back here again.
Such a shame because I live blocks away.
pot stickers.author: Jeannie C.
pot stickers.review: This place is terrible! The food looked pretty bad when I went in but I got some pot stickers because I was starving.  The cost was $4 for 3 pot stickers! It was pretty pricy but again I was starving.  Before handing them over the lady asked if I wanted them microwaved because they were cold.  I just grabbed them and left after paying for them. They were not only cold, but also pretty gross.  I will never go back here again.  Such a shame because I live blocks away.

excerpts: Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes!
Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?!
So very good!
Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.
pot stickers.author: E W.
pot stickers.review:
Friendly, family run small neighborhood restaurant. Great trying Sichuan food here and Cantonese dishes too. Their large soup noodle bowls are yummy and perfectly satisfying  for those cold days! Especially enjoyed their preserved/pickled  vegetable dishes! Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes! Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?! So very good! Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.

excerpts: Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.
Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).
pot stickers.author: Christopher H.
pot stickers.review: Where to start...it recently (in the last year) went through a modest little makeover of the facade and brick outside and may have under gone a management change also??  This place is a diamond in the rough to have on Balboa.  Many thanks to the owners/staff who run the place now.  Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite

excerpts: We ordered an assortment of dishes (boiled dumplings, beef noodle soup that had tasty "handmade" noodles but barely any beef, green onion pancake that was fantastic, Chinese hamburger which was a little odd with too much of the bun, green beans which were probably the highlight) that were all OK to pretty tasty, (except for the soup dumplings which were fairly meh with 5 out of 6 dumplings not having any soup in them and the skin being really thick).
chinese hamburger.author: Mengo Z.
chinese hamburger.review:
Went here for lunch today after strolling Lands End since the nearby Shanghai places all had long waits and I figured the positive Yelp review meant something.  We ordered an assortment of dishes (boiled dumplings, beef noodle soup that had tasty "handmade" noodles but barely any beef, green onion pancake that was fantastic, Chinese hamburger which was a little odd with too much of the bun, green beans which were probably the highlight) that were all OK to pretty tasty, (except for the soup dumplings which were fairly meh with 5 out of 6 dumplings not having any soup in them and the skin being really thick).

The service was friendly and quick but what threw me off was at the end, the waiter came by and asked for our table to all give 5-star Yelp reviews and return we'd get 10% off our check.  The Yelp check-in already gives 10% off and I don't like the feeling of a business trying to "buy" my rating.  Minus one star for that shadiness - I think a much better approach would have been to let us know that they are a newer establishment and ask us to review them on Yelp - I would have happily rated them 4 stars even without the discount.  So if you see 5-star reviews here that are super short (and could have been typed out on a mobile phone), chances are they could have been bribed :-/

excerpts: I was probably drawn there by the fact thaat a Yelper had mentioned a "Chinese hamburger" and (correctly) assumed it was a roujiamo, but since it was past 5:00 when I got there I decided to make that the appetizer to  an early dinner.
chinese hamburger.author: Gary S.
chinese hamburger.review:
Playing Muni Roulette on Market Street yesterday, I decided to jump on the 31 Balboa to check out Village House (鄉村风味). I was probably drawn there by the fact thaat a Yelper had mentioned a "Chinese hamburger" and (correctly) assumed it was a roujiamo, but since it was past 5:00 when I got there I decided to make that the appetizer to  an early dinner. The young woman server was eager to promote the house-made xiaolong bao, dumplings (jiaozi) and noodles, so I ordered a basket of XLB and a lamb dumpling and noodle soup as my mains.

The roujiamo ("Chinese Hamberger" on the menu) was on the small side, but heck, it cost all of  $2.95. The panbread bun was about the right thickness, browned but not greasy, though a bit less dense than some versions. The meat filling was appropriately porky and salty in flavor, though the texture seemed wrong because  it was coarsely chopped (loin?) instead of stewed, so the sandwich was a bit dry as well.

I don't know if they knew what they were getting into, boasting about their house-made xiaolong bao in earshot of both Shanghai Dumpling King and Shanghai House, but they didn't embarrass themselves.  Their XLB is probably better than the last I had at SDK, but not quite as good as I remember Shanghai House's to be (though I haven't been to either of these places in a long time). The wrappers were delicate, and the soup ample, though they need to push the needle away from the salty side of the dial a bit toward the sweet side. But then, those were Beijingese voices floating around the room, not Shanghainese.

The soup was hearty, with six lamb dumplings and a long ton of noodles.  The dumplings were meaty but not particularly lamb-y (but I'd like try them again, outside of soup, to be fair). The noodles were springy and fresh, if not hand pulled. The broth seemed under-seasoned, particularly lacking salt, of all things. Since there was no salt shaker of the condiment tray, I used a bit of soy sauce along with chili paste to sex it up.

The menu contains a lot that will be of interest to fans of Northern Chinese style "dim sum." Chao bing was mentioned by a previous reviewer (in fact Village House has four versions), and they also have such relative rarities as sweet and savory shao bing (saobing), jian bing guozi, ji dan guan bing and doufu nao (which I'll definitely be back soon to try). In addition to other, more familiar  Northern Chinese fare, Village House's menu is augmented with a smattering of Shandong, Shanghainese, Xi'an, Sichuan and Xinjiang offerings.

excerpts: Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes!
Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?!
So very good!
Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.
chinese hamburger.author: E W.
chinese hamburger.review:
Friendly, family run small neighborhood restaurant. Great trying Sichuan food here and Cantonese dishes too. Their large soup noodle bowls are yummy and perfectly satisfying  for those cold days! Especially enjoyed their preserved/pickled  vegetable dishes! Family really enjoyed the kou rou with preserved vegetables, dry fried chicken wings, Chinese hamburger, lamb dumplings, pot stickers, hot sour soup, braised beef noodles, beef stir fried shredded pancake with cabbage , sesame chicken among other dishes.
Look forward to going down the menu and trying everything especially the Ma la hot dishes! Did I mention that dumplings and noodles are fresh and handmade?! So very good! Chefs sometimes bring out just cooked dishes and chat with diners!
Great Value, friendly service and delicious food not to mention peaceful dining experience and easy parking.

excerpts: Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.
Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).
chinese hamburger.author: Christopher H.
chinese hamburger.review: Where to start...it recently (in the last year) went through a modest little makeover of the facade and brick outside and may have under gone a management change also??  This place is a diamond in the rough to have on Balboa.  Many thanks to the owners/staff who run the place now.  Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite

excerpts: Out of curiosity I tried the Chinese hamburger.
It's simple and delicious.
I just wish it had more filling.
I would recommend it as a late-afternoon snack to anyone walking by looking for a quick bite to eat.
My biggest complaint about this place isn't actually about the quality of the food
it's the fact that everything is made to order, which in this case is actually a detriment to their business model.
Dim sum restaurants are supposed to be fast and have small portioned, good quality dumplings at affordable prices.
Village House doesn't really offer that.
The prices are too high for the quality of food they provide and because everything is made to order, you have to wait a minimum of 10 minutes for even a single order of dim sum.
I haven't tried any of their soups yet
and I have seen quite a few people ordering it when they eat in the restaurant.
They look quite good
and I look forward to trying them.
chinese hamburger.author: Chris S.
chinese hamburger.review:
After the previous (and my favorite) dim sum place at this location closed, I was fairly apprehensive about Village House when it opened. When I first walked in I was pleasantly surprised to find that they make all their dim sum fresh, right up front for everyone to see. The atmosphere of the place is nice as well. It's small, quiet, clean and pleasantly decorated. The staff is courteous and more than willing to answer any questions you may have. The size of the menu is decent for a place like this, but what's on the menu is fairly uninspired. There isn't much you won't find at any other generic Chinese-American restaurant. The real question is... is the food any good? 

I have been to Village House half a dozen times over the span of a few weeks to try and get a sense of quality and consistency. Unfortunately, they are one of the most inconsistent restaurants I have ever experienced. The dim sum has ranged from absolutely outstanding to a doughy, under-seasoned mess. the chicken dumpling with green chives is the only one that really blew my mind. The potstickers, which are typically one of my favorite dishes, were a total disappointment. They charge $5.95 for 4 doughy, flavorless pockets of disappointment. I can go to any number of other dim sum places and get 3 for around $2. The spicy dumplings, which were recommended to me as their most popular dish tasted okay, but made me feel ill later that day. Also, more than one my dishes were swimming in oil, which somewhat ruined it for me. Out of curiosity I tried the Chinese hamburger. It's simple and delicious. I just wish it had more filling. I would recommend it as a late-afternoon snack to anyone walking by looking for a quick bite to eat. My biggest complaint about this place isn't actually about the quality of the food it's the fact that everything is made to order, which in this case is actually a detriment to their business model. Dim sum restaurants are supposed to be fast and have small portioned, good quality dumplings at affordable prices. Village House doesn't really offer that. The prices are too high for the quality of food they provide and because everything is made to order, you have to wait a minimum of 10 minutes for even a single order of dim sum. I haven't tried any of their soups yet and I have seen quite a few people ordering it when they eat in the restaurant. They look quite good and I look forward to trying them. Although my experiences with Village House have not been the best so far, I will go again to try different things and see if their consistency improves. 

Overall I believe Village House has the potential to be a great, local dim sum place, but at this point I wouldn't recommend ordering any of the actual dumplings. It is a good place to bring a date for a small meal before seeing a movie at the theater down the street. It's a quiet and pleasant experience, even if the food is subpar.

excerpts: We went there during lunchtime and ordered Mongolian lamb and beef, beef chow mein, "Chinese hamburger" (jia mo) with a soup.
The selection is nothing extraordinary but the experience was quite satisfying.
chinese hamburger.author: Kit R.
chinese hamburger.review: Owners are very friendly and the portions are pretty good for the price. Most dishes were right around $10. We went there during lunchtime and ordered Mongolian lamb and beef, beef chow mein, "Chinese hamburger" (jia mo) with a soup. The selection is nothing extraordinary but the experience was quite satisfying.

excerpts: So far I've tried the chinese hamburger, ready made and fresh made pork dumplings, ready made fried rice, green onion pancake and beef pancake.
The chinese hamburger was a little dry, but the flavor was definitely there!
It's a bit spicy too.
I feel like the buns were what was making it dry, as they were a bit thick and dense.
I wasn't a huge fan of the ready made pork dumplings.
They felt a bit bland to me, but somehow the ones I ordered that were made fresh were much better.
Perhaps it was because they were hot?
When I ordered the green onion pancake I thought it would be the usual fried dough with green onions, but this was instead a fried dough filled with fresh veggies and green onion!
It was -very- good and you get a lot.
I think bits of the dough weren't cooked completely, but I honestly didn't mind in the slightest.
I love the very slightly underdone texture.
The premade fried rice was very bland
but I liked the addition of pineapple to it.
I just threw in a bit of salt when I got home
and it was better.
The beef pancake has to be my favorite so far, though.
chinese hamburger.author: Benny G.
chinese hamburger.review:
I was a huge fan of Jook Time for their cheap, huge selection of dim sum so I was really sad to see it go. I was very wary when I saw a much bigger seating selection while Village House was remodeling, worried that it wouldn't have dim sum options and was purely a sit down place. However, it's looking like they're doing ready to go dim sum, at least a bit! It's definitely more of a sit down place and their ready made food is a little lacking in selection, but it's there and I'm hoping they expand on it more. 

Regardless, I've been there a couple times now and it's been pretty good! I was again worried that it would be a copycat of Shanghai Dumpling King across the street, but their menu is different enough that it works on its own. So far I've tried the chinese hamburger, ready made and fresh made pork dumplings, ready made fried rice, green onion pancake and beef pancake. The chinese hamburger was a little dry, but the flavor was definitely there! It's a bit spicy too. I feel like the buns were what was making it dry, as they were a bit thick and dense. I wasn't a huge fan of the ready made pork dumplings. They felt a bit bland to me, but somehow the ones I ordered that were made fresh were much better. Perhaps it was because they were hot? When I ordered the green onion pancake I thought it would be the usual fried dough with green onions, but this was instead a fried dough filled with fresh veggies and green onion! It was -very- good and you get a lot. I think bits of the dough weren't cooked completely, but I honestly didn't mind in the slightest. I love the very slightly underdone texture. The premade fried rice was very bland but I liked the addition of pineapple to it. I just threw in a bit of salt when I got home and it was better. The beef pancake has to be my favorite so far, though. It's the same kind of green onion pancake dough but wrapped almost crepe style around green onion, various green veggies, beef, cilantro and a really tasty sauce. 

Pricewise it's pretty standard. Prices range between $2.50-$10. With how downhill Shanghai Dumpling King has been feeling, it's nice to have a good lunch option for a similar price point. 

They don't have any music playing, but everyone is very friendly and the wait times for food aren't super long! I've only ever done take out, but I'd like to sit down at some point and see how it goes. Definitely needs music, though. It was pretty quiet in there.  

Overall I definitely recommend it! I'm knocking off a star for the fairly bland premade food, but I have high hopes for the rest of the menu!

excerpts: Beef roll -

just okay, meat was a little flavorless, maybe a little old... 
Beijing noodles - super disappointed in this.
It was sloppily made - noodles overcooked so
when you ate it with the sauce, there's no chew to the noodles and makes the sauce too wet.
XLB -  this was pretty good actually.
I'd order this again.
I wished there was more soup and filling though but the skin was good.
Fish flavored eggplant - Pretty decent taste though a little too greasy.
beef roll.author: Cindy W.
beef roll.review:
Meh - I think this restaurant at best. I wasn't super blown away by any of the items I ordered and would go to another Asian restaurant next time

Beef roll - just okay, meat was a little flavorless, maybe a little old... 
Beijing noodles - super disappointed in this. It was sloppily made - noodles overcooked so when you ate it with the sauce, there's no chew to the noodles and makes the sauce too wet. 
XLB -  this was pretty good actually. I'd order this again. I wished there was more soup and filling though but the skin was good. 
Fish flavored eggplant - Pretty decent taste though a little too greasy. Still okay. 

Waitress was nice and gave us a free red bean cake. It seemed a bit old. I'd suggest frying these fresh because time does make a big difference!

excerpts: We had the XLB, beef roll, braised eggplant, and Beijing bean sauce noodles.
The location is easy to get too but hard to find parking around especially on the weekend.
beef roll.author: Vanessa S.
beef roll.review: Came here to have brunch with friends, and have to admit the food was pretty good but some of the dishes were a bit too bland for my tastes. We had the XLB, beef roll, braised eggplant, and Beijing bean sauce noodles. The location is easy to get too but hard to find parking around especially on the weekend.

excerpts: * Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs.
The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu.
Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.
pan fried pork bun.author: Sterling C.
pan fried pork bun.review: ***One of the best places for quick, inexpensive and delicious Chinese snack/dim sum dishes.*** Especially recommend the pan fried pork bun, spicy dumpling, fennel dumpling (special menu item), and cumin beef ribs. The chef is also super friendly and will gladly make recommendations both on and off the menu. Highly recommended if you're in the mood for authentic Dim Sum plates that won't break the bank.

excerpts: One item we ordered was called Crispy Pot Pancake for $6.95.
I posted a picture of this in the photo section.
It tasted so disappointingly bland that we probably would have been better off ordering Green Pancake that is two dollars less.
The Pork and Shrimp dumpling was yummy enough hence the two stars.
crispy pot pancake.author: Marilyn O.
crispy pot pancake.review: Ordered takeout from here. First, I ordered three items but we only received two of the three items. The two items took too long that we weren't able to wait and reorder the third item and just decided to bring the two items home. One item we ordered was called Crispy Pot Pancake for $6.95. I posted a picture of this in the photo section. It tasted so disappointingly bland that we probably would have been better off ordering Green Pancake that is two dollars less. The Pork and Shrimp dumpling was yummy enough hence the two stars.

excerpts: He even gave us a free sesame red bean pancake as a dessert.
We're definitely coming back to try some of the other delicious looking food on their menu.
sesame red bean pancake.author: Gabriel H.
sesame red bean pancake.review: Was looking for a place to eat around the area and my girlfriend stumbled upon this restaurant on yelp so we decided to give it a try since they have handmade dumplings and noodles and I must say it was as good as we expected and it didn't disappoint at all. We ordered the egg with tomato noodle soup, the chicken and chive dumplings, the braised tofu, and the xiao long bao. Everything tasted great and was delicious. The service was also good. The waitress checked in on us asking if the food was good which was nice and one of the cooks who I think is the owner was even nice enough to come out and refill my tea. He even gave us a free sesame red bean pancake as a dessert. We're definitely coming back to try some of the other delicious looking food on their menu.

excerpts: Dessert = red bean pancakes, hot out of the oven, sweet and with heapings of red bean filling.
red bean pancakes.author: L T.
red bean pancakes.review:
Absolutely scrumptious! We ordered beef noodle soup, wonton noodle soup, spring rolls (the BEST spring rolls I have ever had: packed with veggies, not dry or over-fried, so tasty), shredded pork in wonton wrappers, and black bean noodles. Unbelievably happy with every single dish--the noodles are hand rolled and cut with a great texture, and the soups were incredibly flavorful. The bok choy dish was a huge hit too -- I don't know what they did to this classic veggie dish, but it was unbelievably tasty. Dessert = red bean pancakes, hot out of the oven, sweet and with heapings of red bean filling. 

Service was fast but not so fast that we felt rushed. Waitress and the chef (he came out to say hello and refill our tea) were so nice and welcoming. I will definitely be back with another large group! One of my new favorite restaurants in the Richmond for sure.

excerpts:
:

- Spicy Fish Soup with Pickled Cucumbers
- Stuffed Onion Pancake
- Vegetarian Dumplings (Fried)
spicy fish.author: Marcel M.
spicy fish.review:
Yeah, this place is a FIND. Tucked in the Outer Richmond, Village House has an unassuming exterior, but delicious food. We got the following three dishes (and would be hard-pressed not to get them again):

- Spicy Fish Soup with Pickled Cucumbers
- Stuffed Onion Pancake
- Vegetarian Dumplings (Fried)

The waiter was funny, and the chef came out to make sure we enjoyed the food. The three dishes meshed really well together, and we also got some white rice. The prices were reasonable for the city, and the spice level was perfect for our mild palettes. The menu has a lot of dishes I have not seen at other SF Chinese restaurants.

excerpts: We ordered Sliced Beef in Chili Oil and Egg Fried Rice.
They are both good and cooked in traditional Chinese way.
We love them so much.
Oh and the price is also good, not expensive.
We will come again next time.
sliced beef in chili oil.author: Tian X.
sliced beef in chili oil.review: An unexpected but wonderful experience! The restaurant is clean and the service is great. We ordered Sliced Beef in Chili Oil and Egg Fried Rice. They are both good and cooked in traditional Chinese way. We love them so much. Oh and the price is also good, not expensive. We will come again next time.

excerpts: Highly recommend the sliced beef in chili oil.
sliced beef in chili oil.author: Emma R.
sliced beef in chili oil.review: The waiter gave us excellent service. The soup dumplings were juicy and thin skinned. Highly recommend the sliced beef in chili oil.

excerpts: My favorite dish was the Sliced Beef in Chili Oil - words can not describe this dish, just perfect.
I would recommend this place to anyone.
sliced beef in chili oil.author: Bryan K.
sliced beef in chili oil.review: This was our first time here and our experience was absolutely amazing. The customer service was out of this world. Our server was friendly and funny and engaged us perfectly and always made sure we had enough water or tea. The soup dumplings were phenomenal; perfect amount of soup and the dough was perfectly thin. My favorite dish was the Sliced Beef in Chili Oil - words can not describe this dish, just perfect. I would recommend this place to anyone.

excerpts: What I like is their boiled fish with szhuan pickles (suggest getting mild, it's pretty spicy) and their seafood fried noodles.
Do not get the soy milk.
It's watered down and tastes like artificial milk.
We had to toss the 2 cups we ordered.
Overall, I can't say they are bad, but again it's not always consistent.
boiled fish with szhuan pickles.author: Amy T.
boiled fish with szhuan pickles.review: I feel this place is a hit or miss. Sometimes we order to go and good would taste great and well balanced of flavors. At other times, things are either too salty, too bland, or too spicy. What I like is their boiled fish with szhuan pickles (suggest getting mild, it's pretty spicy) and their seafood fried noodles. Do not get the soy milk. It's watered down and tastes like artificial milk. We had to toss the 2 cups we ordered. Overall, I can't say they are bad, but again it's not always consistent.

excerpts: The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me
and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.
Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite
boiled fish with szhuan pickles.author: Christopher H.
boiled fish with szhuan pickles.review: Where to start...it recently (in the last year) went through a modest little makeover of the facade and brick outside and may have under gone a management change also??  This place is a diamond in the rough to have on Balboa.  Many thanks to the owners/staff who run the place now.  Curteous, quick and thoughful and with interesting menu and nice paper Chinese tales of dumpling and soup on the walls.  It is a Village House type simplicity replete with the classic linoleum and fluorescent lighting sf is known for :)).  House made Xiao Long Bao is ordered almost every time.  Chinese hamburger and pot stickers also good and fried but clean.  Bean paste with noodle is refreshing with raw veggies and satisfying with the pork bean paste and noodle (not house made noodle for this one but?).  The kung pao chicken is a sensation with the chili oil, whole peanut, celery, green pepper, onion, and a haunting after bite that leaves a tingle.  Numb face lamb soup at Mission Chinese only other place I've tried that has the same spice.  The soups come hot and do not taste like they have been cooked in multi dish oils or water and to top off the list are three other really good/great dishes on the menu:  the egg chow mein, the cumin lamb (double yup) and the Boiled Fish with Szhuan Pickles (two thumbs up in the air for this one) - this dish is a new must have and fave for me and I'm a caucasian who doesn't branch far in the seafood selections - food for two and a deep but light broth with white fish and big white hunks of tofu - thick but creamy and a delight.  Xie-xie ni, Cheers and bon appetite
